body: Awesome-- any reason why you're not using the Google cloud storage hook?
@bolkedebruin that makes sense. i just bumped the version in `setup.py` to the lastest (`2.7.8`) for `snakebite`

I agree that the context should expose an `is_backfill` boolean for people to use. In the meantime, the way we've been doing this is adding custom logic in DAGs themselves. Say if you were to add you own `is_backfill = False` at the top of your DAG, you could alter it when running backfill to set that temporarily to True. Based on this new flag, you can change anything in your DAG at will in your script, like skipping that email sending task for instance.

I think the key is to override `__deepcopy__` and skip / reattach the offending objects. There's an example of that here for 2 attributes that caused problems:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L2438

You may want to do something similar for your operator.

Cool, thanks for the workaround.  Another similar piece of information that would be cool to propagate into the task execution code is whether `-f/--force` was included in the invocation, because we have some systems that also have this notion and it would make sense to pass the flag as far as it needs to go.  Is that also useful to you/others?

I haven't gotten around to getting a dev version of Airflow setup, but this is pretty compelling for us, so I think I'll try to work on it soon.  I'd imagine a new argument(s) to the `run(...)` method [here](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L73) would be a good place to start?
@artwr, can you run our local tests against this for a final blessing?! Feel free to merge once you confirm it works.
cc @mistercrunch @r39132 @bolkedebruin
Should we add the rest of the Airbnb team who have been committing/merging? Or this more as a list where each committer represents a company?
@mistercrunch I think if someone has commit access to this repo, they should be listed.
@mistercrunch if you give me a list, I can add
@syvineckruyk any chance to get a sneak peak at your current implementation?

@criccomini the more I thought about it, the more I like the idea of using hooks. I've been working to transform the code.

However, I'm running into major issues with the current GoogleCloudStorageHook. The biggest is an `oauth2client` version conflict that makes it impossible to use `gcloud` (see below) but a few smaller ones are that there's no way to get a Python blob object and I don't know how to do something simple like upload a string to GCS without writing a file first. Worse, every time I try to use it I get an error about empty scopes not being allowed... so the truth is I haven't even been able to do much testing since I actually can't get started.

You're right that the GoogleCloudStorageHook uses Google's Python API client, but that's different from the Google Cloud Platform Python client, which is `gcloud` (https://googlecloudplatform.github.io/gcloud-python/). From the docs:

> What is the relationship between gcloud and the Google APIs Python Client?
> 
> The Google APIs Python Client is a client library for using the broad set of Google APIs. gcloud is built specifically for the Google Cloud Platform and is the recommended way to integrate Google Cloud APIs into your Python applications. If your application requires both Google Cloud Platform and other Google APIs, the 2 libraries may be used by your application.

Unfortunately, in this case it is _not_ possible to use both libraries together because the GoogleCloudStorageHook added `oauth2client<2.0.0` to the airflow requirements (I assume because 2.0.0 introduced some breaking changes to the API client, namely https://github.com/google/oauth2client/issues/401). But the latest `gcloud` requires `oauth2client >= 2.0`. As a result, ironically, I suspect that any airflow users who use `gcloud` are finding that their code is broken after installing airflow master! Even myself, I didn't realize this was the problem until I went digging just now -- we just knew we had to reinstall gcloud after installing airflow, but couldn't figure out why.

I am working on a new PR to create a GCSHook that wraps `gcloud`. At a minimum, I think we need to move the oauth2client requirement into a "gcs_api" extra and out of airflow's default requirements. I will do that in another PR, in case the first PR is held up for any reason. I will design this to work alongside the existing GCP hooks, since I don't want to break anything. I know that your organization must depend heavily on GCP and I _strongly_ recommend that you consider adopting `gcloud` over the API client, if possible. It has bindings for bigquery and datastore. 

Again, I totally appreciate that you guys probably have lots of code in production using the legacy client, but we want to make sure folks can also use `gcloud` without problems :)

This is probably a dumb question, but I have little experience with SQLAlchemy.  I have created a new column for the TaskInstance Model, how do I get airflow to change the database schema?  Initial tests complain about a lack of that column in the db, which is understandable.  I'll be happy to add some more documentation on the CONTRIBUTING page. Thanks!
@Wow that's a bad merge... redoing! Ignore this.
fixed in #1118

> (I assume because 2.0.0 introduced some breaking changes to the API client, namely google/oauth2client#401

Correct.

> I suspect that any airflow users who use gcloud are finding that their code is broken after installing airflow master

Assuming they're not using a virtual environment. I don't think Airflow currently requires gcloud.

I'm cool with switching things to gcloud, but it's going to have to get tested first. You're right. We have a lot of stuff in prod using the current stuff, and it's working fine, so I'm hesitant to change it unless we know it works first.
What about google-api-python-client? That's the actual API, right? Do we want to move that into gcp_api as well?

+1 definitely don't want to force any changes -- just want to avoid conflicts. 

The trouble with airflow/gcloud is that we (just as an example) use gcloud heavily in our own operators/hooks/dags, which of course have to be called by machines with Airflow installed (and, consequently, fail when `oauth2lib` is capped < 2).
Good call! It wasn't in the existing dependencies so I overlooked it.
A good compromise might be to just patch the current hooks to work with oauth2lib >= 2. I think we might just need to switch from Signed JWT to some equivalent.

I'm certainly not opposed to that but if you look at how much more easy/flexible it is to use the gcloud library in #1119 I think you'll agree that it's preferable for any users that aren't already relying on legacy google API code. Working with bigquery, datastore, etc. is also relatively simple. 

For example, it's practically a one-liner (plus some error checking) to support string uploads to GCS (which is needed for shipping the logs) -- I don't know where to start coding that with the API library.

I'm convinced that we should use gcloud. I'm just thinking about how to get from here to there without breaking everything. It looks like that PR adds new hooks, which allows the current ones to be backwards compatible. It also lets us test in parallel. This seems reasonable to me.

Glad to hear it but just to be clear my mission isn't to make you change anything you're doing! In fact the last thing I want is to introduce breaking changes. Just wanted to provide an option for those of us using the nice training wheels of `gcloud`.

If that's the case, as I understand it, the only thing blocking you is the fact that you've got a oauth version conflict. You need 2, and the GCP API stuff conflicts with it. If you have gcp_api and gcp as two separate install packages, I think we can co-exist, right?

Yes, sorry if that wasn't clear -- my PRs make both GCP options available so they can coexist (though they can't be used at the same time to the oauth2client versioning). Users simply choose airflow[gcp_api] or airflow[gcp]. I am writing a brief readme to explain that.
follows #1118

Just created a pull request
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1120
This is my first time to do a pull request, feel free to drop it but I will appreciate it very much if you can review the logic

Could you make it so we can specify the service account from the JSON? We actually run Airflow with multiple service accounts per-hook to get fine-grained permissions. Setting it at the environment variable level doesn't work well with this.
What do you think about migrating the GCS operators to use new hook as part of this?

@criccomini regarding service accounts it should work -- this Hook looks for a "keyfile_path"  in the airflow connection to identify a json service account key. I think there's similar extra parameter for the other GCS Hook. However this one uses json and I think the other one uses p12 if I remember correctly. I am going to make a change so you can pass either a json OR a p12 file to this hook, so you could reuse the same GCS connections.
Pull request here:https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1122
Ah, got it. Missed that. Awesome. Motivation to switch to json. :) We're still on the deprecated p12's for the most part.
No problem, will support both! :) One sec.
@criccomini I think this will now allow you to reuse your existing Airflow connections, but please give it a shot to be sure.

> @criccomini I think this will now allow you to reuse your existing Airflow connections, but please give it a shot to be sure.

Thought: perhaps add backwards-compatible APIs so that the existing GCS operators can work with your new hooks?
I think that's the cleanest approach -- let me see how easily I can make the signatures match.
I'm going to hold off on this until https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1119

@criccomini I'm feeling pretty good about this! the latest one _should_ have full signature compatibility with the previous hook, both at initialization and for the `download` and `upload` methods. Also full support for scopes, which we didn't have before (though note scopes require passing key_path either in the connection or at initialization).

...except for "delegate_to". I'm not familiar with this, unfortunately. You can pass the argument, but it's ignored.

With regard to other operators, at this time our GCP use is focused on GCS/GCE/GKE/CloudSQL/DataProc so I don't think I have the expertise to migrate them. However we are starting to use BigQuery more so maybe that'll change as our workflow evolves.
Shouldn't the ssh connection type also be added to www/views.py -> ConnectionModelView.form_choices? Would be awesome if these would somehow be configurable through plugins as well.

Well it's also possible that this parent process gets killed as well. Luckily we send and monitor heartbeats and kill zombie tasks.

If we really wanted to capture this very rare case, we should refactor that logic instead of duplicating it.

Do you guys kill -9 a lot of tasks? I a normal kill should be clean (by SIGINT / SIGTERM handling), though I haven't run much tests since I first wrote the code...
@mistercrunch @criccomini
@r39132 @mistercrunch @bolkedebruin updated. LMK if it's good to go.
closing in favor of #1125 which builds on #1119.
Fine to me

There are several reasons we need take special care of the spawned process(TaskInstance.run):
1. As you said the LocalTaskJob process has already been taken care of by kill_zombies
2. We don't check the return code of the spawned process, it will keep in ''running" state forever, if it's in a pool, it's wasting a slot in the pool. I did see one pool is full with those running tasks so no other tasks can proceed
3. the LocalTaskJob process is usually very lightweight so there's little chance it will be killed, but the spawned process sometimes may do a heavy job like using lots of memory. In such case, they are easily being killed by some external daemon monitoring process because of out of memeory, too much FD,etc. Like in some cases, all the process is running in a docker, so a docker daemon will kill those spawned process.  

Thanks again for the quick reply

I also met the same issue. My way is,
1. Turn off the DAG.
2. Clear the tasks with future
3. Delete the DAG Runs which their status is running
4. Turn on the DAG

From my point of view, since the DagRun class doesn't have a **init** method which grabs the current timestamp (in 1.6.2 it should be datetime.now(), but I didn't find the difinition of func.now()) everytime we instantiate a DagRun object, I think the initialization of start_date will only be done once when the class file is loaded no matter what method it calls within its definition? First option to look at is change some parameters related to timeout in /etc/my.cnf . See http://piwik.org/faq/troubleshooting/faq_183/ . And https://www.drupal.org/node/259580 .

For airflow we might need to look at how we do sessions (didn't really check) @mistercrunch http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6471549/avoiding-mysql-server-has-gone-away-on-infrequently-used-python-flask-server#6473271
@griffinqiu @krisskross did you have a look at the sql_alchemy_pool_recycle option? It defaults to 3600 and that might be too long in your case.
